text: I just made a new project, and the precompilation is stuck and never finishes. Is there some cached precompilation I can delete to see if it's due to corrupted state?

elements.text: I just made a new project, and the precompilation is stuck and never finishes. Is there some cached precompilation I can delete to see if it's due to corrupted state?

text: Can we cross post this publicly to <https://discourse.julialang.org|Discourse> for further visibility? React with :bridge: on the message above to approve. <https://github.com/JuliaCommunity/SlackBridge/blob/main/README.md#faq|More info here>
Thanks, hm, that did not work. It did re-compile everything, but when I got to my project itself, it's still stuck

elements.text: Thanks, hm, that did not work. It did re-compile everything, but when I got to my project itself, it's still stuck

text:
I have a project whose file structure is like this
```.
├── Manifest.toml
├── Project.toml
└── src
   └── buildref.jl```
and the content of `buildref` is something like
```module t

using Pkg
Pkg.activate(".")
Pkg.instantiate()

# a few "using" packages
main()

end # module```
:thinking_face:

elements.text: I have a project whose file structure is like this

module t

using Pkg
Pkg.activate(".")
Pkg.instantiate()

# a few "using" packages
main()

end # module

text: not sure it's related to the precompilation  issue, but a package doing those `Pkg` operations inside it is rather unconventional

elements.text: not sure it's related to the precompilation  issue, but a package doing those
operations inside it is rather unconventional

text: Agreed. I didn't want to make it a package, actually, just a script with proper dependency management.

elements.text: Agreed. I didn't want to make it a package, actually, just a script with proper dependency management.

text: What makes it a package as opposed to a Julia file that just happens to activate the correct environment?

elements.text: What makes it a package as opposed to a Julia file that just happens to activate the correct environment?

text: yeah, not sure, the line between them is probably a bit blurred
